comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: What's interesting is the quality and resolution of the glass plate in comparison to the presumably 35mm photo from 1990.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: A good big one beats a good little one every time. Even medium format beats 35mm hands down so you may guess what resolution a 19 x 13cm glass negative has.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: What is really interesting as regards the buildings is how many of the large two storey ones are missing from the 1990 shot.  Population density had obviously dropped considerably.  The number of farms/cottages and more remote buildings is no greater. The Abbey in the foreground was an Augustinian Priory.  A neighbour of mine was from Ballinskelligs and her father was a noted Gaelgoir and author who wrote about the area.  He published a book about Ballinskelligs just before he died a couple of years back.

comment._content: Is this photo taken from Horse Island, looking North-West to Ballinskelligs? maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,444034,564432,4,7 Or am I lost?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I wondered too - I think both photographers were on the mainland, French slightly to the left, on this hill, looking almost due north - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Ballinskelligs&hl=en&ll... Co-ordinates - 51.808393 N,-10.272555 W Puzzled by the lack of seawall / jetty on the island / isthmus in this photo. Anyone know when it was built? It seems to have caused the erosion (once a beachcomber, always a beachcomber!)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The pier right of  the castle is not on the 1896 OS 25" map, nor is the seawall by the abbey (with the three supports).

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Just scanning the OSI maps of the area and in the next bay down is "TRANASASSANACH" The Strand of the English, I love it.
